Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: New Catalysts for Chemicals Production
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps team project includes possible commercialization of new, selective catalysts that provide safer and more efficient production of chemicals and chemical products from petrochemical and renewable feedstocks at lower cost, with less chemical waste, and with lower energy requirements. Catalysts are substances that dramatically increase reaction rates for desired products. In many cases, commercial production of a chemical product is not possible without the use of a catalyst. Approximately 90% of all chemical production requires the use of a catalyst in at least one step of the production process. This includes the production of bulk chemicals, plastics and polymers, synthetic rubber, pharmaceuticals, agricultural chemicals, fuels, and chemicals used in consumer products and in the food industry. The need for new catalysts that are more selective and provide more efficient chemical production at lower cost spans all sectors of the chemical industry.

This I-Corps project focuses on a unique family of patented constrained geometry ligands and metal catalysts that have potential applications in several of the market segments of the chemical industry. Development of this technology for specific applications is in the preliminary stages, but basic proof-of-concept of proprietary constrained geometry catalyst production has been demonstrated and patent coverage has been obtained. Based on initial customer interviews, the team will focus on evaluating customer needs in the polymer, rubber, and petroleum refining segments of the chemical industry. Specifically, the team will explore customer needs for more selective, more active, and less expensive catalysts for conversion of petrochemical and renewable feedstocks to polymers and other value-added products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this I-Corps project, our team explored commercialization opportunities for proprietary (US Patent 8,524,846 B1, 2013) constrained geometry catalysts that have potential applications in olefin polymerization, olefin oligomerization, olefin metathesis , olefin hydroamination, and the polymerization of polar monomers.  The objectives of the project were to learn about entrepreneurship and how to form a start-up, to discover potential customers and the proper market segment for our technology, to refine the value propositions that this technology offers, and to decide if the intellectual property should be licensed to existing companies or if a start-up company should be formed to commercialize this technology.  We also sought information about customers’ catalyst needs, how potential new catalysts come to be identified by users, the catalyst adoption process, the channels used to introduce new catalysts to customers, and the revenue models that drive adoption and use.

Our NSF I-Corps team completed the seven-week training sessions with the teaching team in the fall of 2016, including the kick-off workshop and closing event held in Arlington, Virginia.  During these sessions, and with guidance and feedback from the teaching team, we developed a business model canvas with a strong focus on identifying customer segments and refining our value propositions for new olefin polymerization catalysts.  We also explored customer relationships, key partners, key activities, resources, potential revenue streams and cost structures for a potential start-up.

Our team interviewed 102 individuals during the seven week I-Corps training period and continued interviews throughout the grant period.  Overall we conducted a total of 244 interviews by phone, Skype, or in person.  In-person interviews were conducted at individual companies and at numerous trade shows and exhibits, including the following:  PACK EXPO in Chicago on November 7-8, 2016;  American Institute of Chemical Engineers  (AIChE) Conference in San Francisco on November 12-17, 2016;  CPhI North America/Inform Ex Pharmaceutical Tradeshow in Philadelphia on May 16-18, 2017;  Specialty and Agro Chemicals America Tradeshow in Charleston, SC on September 6-8, 2017; 16th Annual Contract Pharma Contracting and Outsourcing Conference in New Brunswick, NJ on September 14-15, 2017;  PACK EXPO Las Vegas/Healthcare Packaging EXPO 2017 in Las Vegas on September 25-27, 2017;  19th Annual SPE TPO Automotive Engineered Polyolefins Conference in Detroit on October 1-4, 2017; International Elastomer Conference in Cleveland on October 9-12, 2017;  and the Outsourced Pharma Conference and Exhibition in San Francisco on October 17-18, 2017.

We interviewed directors of business development, directors of research and development, research chemists, process engineers, and sales managers representing all points along the supply chains.  For polyolefins, this included petrochemical producers, catalyst manufacturers, polymer producers, polymer compounders, and end-users in packaging and automobile parts suppliers.  Although economic considerations (e.g., catalyst activity, selectivity, form, cost per ton of polymer, and ability to function in existing infrastructure) are important, we learned that new catalyst development is driven by the need for improved polymer properties.  For example, the increasing use of polypropylene and the need for improved properties of polypropylene in the automobile industry is driven by lightweighting and intermaterials substitution of polypropylene for heavier metals under the hood of the car and for interior components.  The automobile industry needs polypropylene with increased thermal stability, improved impact resistance, better scratch resistance, and improved ability to retain color.  In packaging applications for food, beverages, and consumer goods, the quest for new catalysts is driven by the need for polyolefins with improved oxygen barrier properties and flexibility without the use of restricted additives.  In other market segments, there is a need for increased melt strength and burst strength of polyolefins, such as in piping.  Thus, catalyst manufacturers and polymer producers need catalysts that will help them provide these improved polyolefin properties to end-users.

As we continued developing our business model canvas, we included customer segments and value propositions for olefin oligomerization, olefin metathesis, and polar monomer polymerization catalysts.

Further technology development was initiated with NSF I-Corps funding and guided by the value propositions refined and the lessons learned during this project.  Technology development continues with funding from the University of Toledo Rocket Fuel Fund, a fund partially established with a grant from the Department of Commerce to the University of Toledo.  We will consider whether to license this technology, collaborate with an established company as a co-development partner, and/or form a start-up depending on the success of the ongoing technology development efforts.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2018
Modified by: Mark R Mason
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: During this I-Corps project, our team explored commercialization opportunities for proprietary (US Patent 8,524,846 B1, 2013) constrained geometry catalysts that have potential applications in olefin polymerization, olefin oligomerization, olefin metathesis , olefin hydroamination, and the polymerization of polar monomers. The objectives of the project were to learn about entrepreneurship and how to form a start-up, to discover potential customers and the proper market segment for our technology, to refine the value propositions that this technology offers, and to decide if the intellectual property should be licensed to existing companies or if a start-up company should be formed to commercialize this technology. We also sought information about customers? catalyst needs, how potential new catalysts come to be identified by users, the catalyst adoption process, the channels used to introduce new catalysts to customers, and the revenue models that drive adoption and use. Our NSF I-Corps team completed the seven-week training sessions with the teaching team in the fall of 2016, including the kick-off workshop and closing event held in Arlington, Virginia. During these sessions, and with guidance and feedback from the teaching team, we developed a business model canvas with a strong focus on identifying customer segments and refining our value propositions for new olefin polymerization catalysts. We also explored customer relationships, key partners, key activities, resources, potential revenue streams and cost structures for a potential start-up. Our team interviewed 102 individuals during the seven week I-Corps training period and continued interviews throughout the grant period. Overall we conducted a total of 244 interviews by phone, Skype, or in person. In-person interviews were conducted at individual companies and at numerous trade shows and exhibits, including the following: PACK EXPO in Chicago on November 7-8, 2016; American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) Conference in San Francisco on November 12-17, 2016; CPhI North America/Inform Ex Pharmaceutical Tradeshow in Philadelphia on May 16-18, 2017; Specialty and Agro Chemicals America Tradeshow in Charleston, SC on September 6-8, 2017; 16th Annual Contract Pharma Contracting and Outsourcing Conference in New Brunswick, NJ on September 14-15, 2017; PACK EXPO Las Vegas/Healthcare Packaging EXPO 2017 in Las Vegas on September 25-27, 2017; 19th Annual SPE TPO Automotive Engineered Polyolefins Conference in Detroit on October 1-4, 2017; International Elastomer Conference in Cleveland on October 9-12, 2017; and the Outsourced Pharma Conference and Exhibition in San Francisco on October 17-18, 2017. We interviewed directors of business development, directors of research and development, research chemists, process engineers, and sales managers representing all points along the supply chains. For polyolefins, this included petrochemical producers, catalyst manufacturers, polymer producers, polymer compounders, and end-users in packaging and automobile parts suppliers. Although economic considerations (e.g., catalyst activity, selectivity, form, cost per ton of polymer, and ability to function in existing infrastructure) are important, we learned that new catalyst development is driven by the need for improved polymer properties. For example, the increasing use of polypropylene and the need for improved properties of polypropylene in the automobile industry is driven by lightweighting and intermaterials substitution of polypropylene for heavier metals under the hood of the car and for interior components. The automobile industry needs polypropylene with increased thermal stability, improved impact resistance, better scratch resistance, and improved ability to retain color. In packaging applications for food, beverages, and consumer goods, the quest for new catalysts is driven by the need for polyolefins with improved oxygen barrier properties and flexibility without the use of restricted additives. In other market segments, there is a need for increased melt strength and burst strength of polyolefins, such as in piping. Thus, catalyst manufacturers and polymer producers need catalysts that will help them provide these improved polyolefin properties to end-users. As we continued developing our business model canvas, we included customer segments and value propositions for olefin oligomerization, olefin metathesis, and polar monomer polymerization catalysts. Further technology development was initiated with NSF I-Corps funding and guided by the value propositions refined and the lessons learned during this project. Technology development continues with funding from the University of Toledo Rocket Fuel Fund, a fund partially established with a grant from the Department of Commerce to the University of Toledo. We will consider whether to license this technology, collaborate with an established company as a co-development partner, and/or form a start-up depending on the success of the ongoing technology development efforts.
